nodes.description: Wednesday a suicide bomber detonated at a Kabul sports hall in a Shia neighborhood
nodes.support_text: An hour after a suicide bomber blew himself up at a sports hall in a heavily Shia neighbourhood on Wednesday, a car packed with explosives detonated as journalists and security forces gathered at the scene, police said.

nodes.description: An hour later a car bomb exploded at the same site while journalists and security forces were present
nodes.support_text: a car packed with explosives detonated as journalists and security forces gathered at the scene, police said.

nodes.description: Tolo News reported two of its journalists were killed in the attack
nodes.support_text: Tolo News, Afghanistan’s largest private broadcaster, said two of its journalists were killed in the attack.

nodes.description: NAI stated at least four journalists were wounded in the second explosion
nodes.support_text: NAI said at least four journalists were wounded in the second explosion.

nodes.description: Afghan President Ashraf Ghani condemned the attacks as crimes against humanity
nodes.support_text: The Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani, said in a statement: ‘An attack on civilians and media workers of the country is an attack on freedom of speech and a crime against humanity.’

nodes.description: Pahlawan Shir confirmed over 30 people died, including wrestlers, and located a critical injured coach
nodes.support_text: Pahlawan Shir, the director of the wrestling club, said: ‘I was outside when the first explosion happened, which has killed over 30 people, many of them wrestlers. I was searching for my coach, I have finally found him in the … hospital. He is in a critical condition.’

nodes.description: Interior Ministry officials confirmed at least 20 casualties
nodes.support_text: A spokesman for the interior ministry said at least 20 people were killed. An Afghan security source confirmed the numbers.

nodes.description: Witnesses described the bomber killing guards before detonating inside the wrestling club
nodes.support_text: People who claimed to have witnessed the attack said the bomber killed the guards at the club before blowing himself up inside.

nodes.description: Mohammad Hanif documented casualties via Facebook, noting athletes were among victims
nodes.support_text: Mohammad Hanif said on Facebook: ‘The bomber detonated inside where a large number of athletes had gathered. There are a lot of dead and wounded.’

nodes.description: The attack marked the deadliest against Kabul's Shia population since 15 August
nodes.support_text: It was the deadliest on Kabul’s Shia population since 15 August, when a suicide bomber blew himself up in an education centre, killing dozens of students.

nodes.description: ISIS claimed responsibility for the 15 August education center bombing that killed students
nodes.support_text: ISIS said it was behind that attack, which drew international condemnation.

nodes.description: April 30 saw twin explosions in Kabul killing 9 journalists and 16 others
nodes.support_text: On 30 April. Nine journalists and 16 other people were killed in twin explosions in Kabul.

nodes.description: Taliban announced Jalaluddin Haqqani's death, linked to prior Kabul attacks
nodes.support_text: On Tuesday the Taliban announced the death of Jalaluddin Haqqani, who founded the eponymous militant group widely suspected of being behind some of the attacks in Kabul claimed by Isis.

nodes.description: 记者和安保人员聚集现场
nodes.support_text: An hour after a suicide bomber blew himself up at a sports hall in a heavily Shia neighbourhood on Wednesday, a car packed with explosives detonated as journalists and security forces gathered at the scene, police said.

nodes.description: 受害者正在备考大学入学考试
nodes.support_text: 受害者正在备考大学入学考试

edges.support_text: An hour after a suicide bomber blew himself up at a sports hall in a heavily Shia neighbourhood on Wednesday, a car packed with explosives detonated as journalists and security forces gathered at the scene, police said.
journalists and security forces gathered at the scene
Tolo News, Afghanistan’s largest private broadcaster, said two of its journalists were killed in the attack.
NAI said at least four journalists were wounded in the second explosion.
The Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani, said in a statement: ‘An attack on civilians and media workers of the country is an attack on freedom of speech and a crime against humanity.’
People who claimed to have witnessed the attack said the bomber killed the guards at the club before blowing himself up inside.
Mohammad Hanif said on Facebook: ‘The bomber detonated inside where a large number of athletes had gathered. There are a lot of dead and wounded.’
Tolo News reported two of its journalists were killed in the attack.

It was the deadliest on Kabul’s Shia population since 15 August, when a suicide bomber blew himself up in an education centre, killing dozens of students. Isis said it was behind that attack, which drew international condemnation.
ISIS said it was behind that attack, which drew international condemnation.
On Tuesday the Taliban announced the death of Jalaluddin Haqqani, who founded the eponymous militant group widely suspected of being behind some of the attacks in Kabul claimed by Isis.
